newsitem.title: SPAIN: Spanish unions plan cascade of anti-budget strikes.
newsitem.headline: Spanish unions plan cascade of anti-budget strikes.

text.p: Unions representing Spanish civil servants on Thursday called for a series of strikes culminating in a mass march on Madrid on November 23 to protest at a wage freeze in the government's strict 1997 budget draft.

A union spokesman said the workers had agreed to a heavy schedule of labour action throughout November as a means to pressure the conservative Popular Party administration into letting public sector salaries rise in line with inflation.
The government's tight budget was designed to whip Spain's finances into shape to join the single European currency.
The unions plan staggered one-hour strikes the first week of November to shut down the central, regional and local governments, courts, postal services, schools and hospitals.
In the following two weeks they are calling two-hour strikes for the central government, police forces and all services region by region.
The unions are to reconvene after the march on Madrid to decide new measures if the government has not redrafted the budget to provide public sector salary raises.
